captions.text: (Music)
Sometimes when I'm on a long plane flight,
I gaze out at all those mountains and deserts
and try to get my head around how vast our Earth is.
And then I remember that there's an object we see every day
that would literally fit one million Earths inside it.
The sun seems impossibly big,
but in the great scheme of things, it's a pinprick,
one of about 400 billion stars in the Milky Way galaxy,
which you can see on a clear night as a pale, white mist stretched across the sky.
And it gets worse.
There are maybe 100 billion galaxies detectable by our telescopes,
so if each star was the size of a single grain of sand,
just the Milky Way has enough stars to fill
a 30 foot by 30 foot stretch of beach three feet deep with sand.
And the entire Earth doesn't have enough beaches
to represent the stars in the overall universe.
Such a beach would continue for literally hundreds of millions of miles.
Holy Stephen Hawking, that is a lot of stars.
But he and other physicists now believe in
a reality that is unimaginably bigger still.
I mean, first of all, the 100 billion galaxies within range of our telescopes
are probably a minuscule fraction of the total.
Space itself is expanding
at an accelerating pace. The vast majority of the galaxies
are separating from us so fast
that light from them may never reach us.
Still, our physical reality here on Earth
is intimately connected to those distant, invisible galaxies.
We can think of them as part of our universe.
They make up a single, giant edifice,
obeying the same physical laws and all made from the same types of atoms, electrons,
protons, quarks, neutrinos that make up you and me.
However, recent theories in physics,
including one called string theory,
are now telling us there could be countless other universes,
built on different types of particles,
with different properties, obeying different laws.
Most of these universes could never support life,
and might flash in and out of existence in a nanosecond,
but nonetheless, combined
they make up a vast multiverse of possible universes.
in up to 11 dimensions, featuring wonders beyond our wildest imagination.
And the leading version of string theory
predicts a multiverse made of up to 10 to the 500 universes.
That's a one followed by 500 zeroes,
a number so vast that if every atom in our observable universe
had its own universe
and all of the atoms in all of those universes
each had their own universe,
and you repeated that for two more cycles,
you'd still be at a tiny fraction of the total --
namely, one trillion trillion trillion trillion trillion trillion trillion trillion trillion trillion trillion trillion trillion trillion trillionth.
But even that number is minuscule compared to
another number: infinity.
Some physicists think the space-time continuum
is literally infinite, and that it contains an infinite number
of so-called pocket universes with varying properties.
How's your brain doing?
But quantum theory adds a whole new wrinkle.
I mean, the theory's been proven true beyond all doubt,
but interpreting it is baffling.
And some physicists think you can only un-baffle it
if you imagine that huge numbers of parallel universes
are being spawned every moment,
and many of these universes would actually be very like the world we're in,
would include multiple copies of you.
In one such universe, you'd graduate with honors and marry the person of your dreams.
In another, not so much.
There are still some scientists who would say, hogwash.
The only meaningful answer to the question of how many universes there are is one,
only one universe.
And a few philosophers and mystics
might argue that even our own universe is an illusion.
So, as you can see,
right now there is no agreement on this question,
not even close.
All we know is, the answer is somewhere between zero and infinity.
Well, I guess we know one other thing:
This is a pretty cool time to be studying physics.
We just might be undergoing
the biggest paradigm shift in knowledge that humanity has ever seen.

title: How many universes are there? - Chris Anderson

comments.text:

perfectly with 11 dimensions and the high weirdness of the quantum realms.

comments.author: Michael Hess

comments.text:
Well there can't be an infinite number of something. It's just that there 
is so much of it that you say that there's an infinite number of it just 
because you can't count it all. Imagine a multiverse, and imagine if all of 
them had blackholes which scientists say that they store other universes in 
them that also have blackholes that store other universes.  But there is a 
problem, inside blackholes everything is smaller and the smaller you get 
there is less space. Image that there is no space, what then? It all stops, 
so we can't say that there is an infinite amout of universes, but we can 
say that there is so much that we can't count them all.﻿

comments.author: John Marr

comments.text:
You are correct in your approach regarding science. However, given the 
strange and baffling quantum theory, one is led to believe that there is at 
least a possibility of there being more than one universe. (Of course, that 
would defeat the very definition of universe, but I digress).

In quantum theory, one learns that everything exists and doesn't exist all 
at once. Everything exists as a wave of probability. When it comes to the 
course of Time, which we really know nothing about, for all we know, all 
possibilities could exist in multiple "verses". This is thanks to entropy.

comments.text:
+Russell Hopkins “It has to be infinite, how can it possibly not be..”

*Argument from personal incredulity*. There is zero evidence that there are 
other universes exist other than your wild imagination. And even if they 
did exist. They would still need to have a beginning. The first law of 
thermodynamics does NOT allow the universe or meta-universe to be eternal. 
If it was, all its usable energy would have already been irreversibly loss, 
and it’d be static. Deal with it.


NEXT.
comments.author: ByRTD yO (byRTD)

comments.text:
+Russell Hopkins The big bang is a FACT. *Deal with it*. It’s a waste of 
time to argue with someone who denies science.

First of all, the universe could be infinite, that still does not mean that 
it has always existed because it hasn’t. It began to exist. An infinite 
regress is an impossibility. I’ll give you this analogy.  Imagine that 
there is a book that explains everything you’ve ever asked, you want that 
book and you ask me if I have it and I say no, I have to get it from my 
brother. And then I go ask my brother and then he says that he needs to get 
it from his friend. and this goes on and on for infinity. In that case, NO 
ONE actually has the book. That’s how existence work. Existence is passed 
down by the chain of cause and effect. If there is no first cause, 
something that has always existed and has existence by its own nature, then 
existence could never be passed down the chain and if that was the case, we 
would NEVER get it, but we did get it! That means that there is a first 
cause, a God. <-------Killing your argument and your faith


*Next*
comments.author: ByRTD yO (byRTD)

comments.author: Russell “Rascal blenz” Hopkins

comments.text:
+Russell Hopkins  “the universe has probably always existed,”

*Laughably WRONG*. If the universe had always existed, all its usable 
energy would have already been irreversibly loss, therefore the universe 
would be static. Hint---> It is expanding. Also, if the universe had always 
existed, its entropy would have already reached maximum equilibrium. Hint-
---> The universe has a really low entropy<------*Killing your argument and 
your faith*. The idea that the universe could be eternal has already been 
debunked by science. Deal with it ;)

*NEXT*
comments.author: ByRTD yO (byRTD)

comments.text:
+Louis Liu Wrong. Science gives overwhelming evidence for God such as the 
fact that the universe had a beginning and is not eternal as it was once 
thought which means that it requires a sufficient cause to bring it into 
existence. In fact, we now know that matter, time, and space began at the 
big bang which means that the cause is immaterial, eternal, and 
transcendent, a God. Also, the extreme fine-tuning of the fundamental 
constants of the universe are also irrefutable evidence. How fine-tuned? 
Take for example the cosmological constant. If it would have been faster by 
just 1 in 10^122, the universe would have expanded too fast at the 
beginning of the expansion and would have collapsed back onto itself, if it 
was slower by 1 in 10^122, the universe would have expanded too slow to 
ever formed galaxies, stars, and planets. To put that number into 
perspective, imagine a blind man and ALL the atoms in the entire observable 
universe. One atom represents the right cosmological constants, the blind 
man would have to pick that atom among the trillions and trillions and 
trillions of atoms. There are about 10 more of these constants that are on 
a knife-edge to allow order and complexity in the universe.  

More evidence is the digital code in DNA. The chemical bases in DNA that 
code for functional proteins are running just like zeros and ones in a 
computer program or alphabetic characters in a written language. When you 
see a message written in the sand beach, you wouldn't invoke the ocean ties 
to explain it would you? You obviously would assume it came from an 
intelligence, yet there are more than 10,000 books worth of information in 
the simplest living cell. All precisely arranged in meaningful and precise 
sequence. Anytime we’ve found specified information like this and traced it 
back to its source wether it was in the form of a newspaper article, a 
computer program,a hieroglyphic inscription or encoded in a radio signal, 
there was always an intelligent agent behind that information

If it wasn’t for science, atheists would still be believing in the 
spontaneous generation nonsense and their eternal universe as evidence that 
a creator wasn’t necessary, but science killed their faith. So, I celebrate 
 it ;)

Consider yourself schooled.

*NEXT*

comments.text:
+ByRTD yO  It seems to me that your line of argument is based on the 
principle of falsifiability. For the starters, it's a philosophical 
argument which is in contradiction with itself, the Principle of 
falsifiability is itself non-falsifiable. Although philosophers deal with 
such a things on a daily basis, in science such self-contradictory 
statements are paradoxes at best which should be carefully used, avoiding 
the sloppy like one I can see here.
You are only partly correct. Multiverse is an idea and there are different 
instances where it is invoked. Bubble universes, super-horizon Multiverse, 
Multiverse of string landscape are either different regions of (extended) 
space-time, which can interact but their interaction scale is currently 
inaccessible to us. But in principle, they make falsifiable claims. Can we 
ever test it? No one knows. There are some hopes that it might have left 
imprints on CMB, that's what we are currently doing right now.
There are some models of multiverse such as parallel universes of Quantum 
mechanics, which do not interact by their definition, hence 
non-falsifiable. But don't assume you got it right. This idea is invoked in 
completely different & redundant circumstance, the interpretation of wave 
function collapse in Quantum mechanics and yes it is not science. You 
really do not need any interpretation of Quantum mechanics in order to do 
Quantum mechanics or Quantum field theories & beyond.

described as follows.

Premise

1) Everything that begins to exist has a cause.

2) God didn't begin to exist.

3) Therefore, God does not need a cause

4) Given premise (1) and (2) God is eternal and uncaused.

comments.text:
Ha ha, “…sounds like a fruity Ken Ham.” Good ole Ken is a four-winged fruit 
fly—and he flew around with the dinosaurs (ha ha). Anyway, where is the 
science in this multiverse, talk? If one is going to go down from our 
comfortable ‘place’ in scale to the Plank limit(s)or also up from our 
comfortable scale to the same size limit (as we went down to the Plank 
limit); then why the problem? We call the Plank limit the boundary where 
all measurements break down and become meaningless—if we (scientists) can 
say that going ‘down’ in scale is OK, then too what not ‘up’ in scale? 
Science is supposed to be testable and falsifiable—I do not see this as 
possible (with multiverse talk). So then we need to rename the ‘talk’ as 
philosophical meta-physics--a belief, like too is religion. We can 
wonder…just like many religious folks also wonder (in awe) of just what in 
the heck is going on and what we are?      
One point science seems to know is that what we are and what is in our 
reality is…it is all energy.  Matter is energy; matter is ‘frozen’ energy; 
just as ice is frozen water (an attempt to analogize by common 
understanding).   We walk around not realizing how absolutely strange this 
situation is (that we are in). Once more if ya can blow off that strange 
concept then how is it that ‘we’ (as an individual) have conscious 
understanding of ideas such as fairness, numbers, perfection, love, and 
time etc etc etc (all the abstract thoughts are not ‘solid’ matter 
definitions and so cannot be defined by science).  We do not seem to be 
just biological bugs—meat robots, but rather conscious observers and moral 
agents—this is weird! To deal with the understanding of infinite regress 
(to multiple universes) such knowledge leaves our infinite understanding 
brain. We have a brain that can understand those ‘things’ that seem 
infinite but that we struggle to rationalize as such. We want a situation 
where what begins has an end.  That could be because we see too much of 
that around us—at our comfortable scale…that begins and then ends.  Put 
this into google “scale of the universe” load the program and move the 
slider to grasp the scales down and also up. Although the depth of the 
scales boggles the mind; the scale, itself, had a beginning and has an 
end—and you can understand it. If ya dig into the quantum world then you 
might conjure there is an infinite set of universes but then if one can 
define a set of universes does that make it infinite? Isn’t infinite (by 
its own definition), undefinable; immeasurable? But what about the 
knowledge of it; of any’thing’ or pattern or symmetry? 
                       
We know there was a beginning to matter but we do not know what was, 
“before the beginning” (sounds a bit like an oxymoron). But that’s not 
totally correct…we do know something about what was around before the 
beginning…we know that matter was NOT around before the beginning, and 
neither was space or time. What is left? ANS:  Is it nothing…that is left?  
ANS: What about information; Code; Intelligence? If there was order written 
into the energy to code it into form (like life is coded into design by 
DNA) then that intelligence could be linked in some manner to what it is we 
are (and how it is that we can think…and conjure up some strange odd and 
abstract thoughts and then garner from our testing the basis of scientific 
thought?).  One thing could be certain, if there is any credence to this 
idea then if it is true and we could discover and communicate with such 
energy then to call it deity would not sound weird or unreasonable (we like 
to be…reasonable).  I don’t want to necessarily wiggle religion into the 
cracks that our education endures, but darn it something that is not a 
thing is going on and whatever it is, it is beyond the science aspect (or 
education) for science deals only with the material (matter) of reality…but 
what is going on here has gone past that, and up in scale or down in scale 
to the edge of the understanding that our brain seems able to deal with and 
desires to have knowledge of.              ﻿

comments.author: Simran Wasu

comments.text:
OKaaaa, hold your C-squared. Nothing in the universe is moving greater than 
the speed of light. As odd as this might sound, it is the "fabric of space 
time that is expanding faster (or at) the speed of light". Speed is 
relative! and so if the 'fabric' is moving faster than the speed of light 
then relatively those 'things' in that fabric are not moving faster than 
the speed of light. Example: if you are standing on a flatbed-car of a 
train and (let's say the train flatcar is moving at the speed of 
light--that it represents the fabric of the universe) and then you run from 
the end of the flatbed to the front of the flatbed...in this case you do 
NOT add the speeds of the flatbed (train/fabric) to your own running speed 
to figure out your total speed. Why not? because motion is relative as 
Einstein's formula states of General and Special Relativity states. So 
although we are being carried through space by an accelerating fabric or 
space/time we are NOT moving in that fabric faster than the speed of 
light.  This is also happening when you move...even the simplest times 
throughout your day it is just that we move in such a small amount of the 
percentage of light speed that we do not cognitively comprehend this. And 
so in our 'world' we add speeds to get a total speed...but get close to the 
speed of light and instead of increasing in speed, time slows down and 
dilates and space warps and lengths of 'things' shorten...AND I believe 
that somewhere in all this (high speed) matter has to revert back to 
energy!  

There is also the problem of dark matter, that in this, case helps. Dark 
Matter is known to exists because of the great rotational speed of galaxies 
at their outer edges. The speed is too fast...if there were no dark matter 
to hold the galaxies together then the outer 'objects' would fly away from 
the great rotational energy they have. Instead something holds them AND 
then the whole unit (the galaxy) moves at an accelerating speed!  
Glue paper dots from a paper punch to a stretchy rubber sheet, then pull 
the rubber apart from two opposites ends with EVEN speed. notice that the 
dots move, but the dots themselves do not stretch, ONLY the spaces between 
the dots stretches. Also notice that if you focus your eyes on only one dot 
then all the other dots look to be moving away from it...faster and faster; 
then focus your eyes on another dot and re-stretch the sheet and then that 
dot will look like IT is the center and all the other dots including the 
first one are moving away...and the dots that are furthest away look to be 
moving even faster than the closest dots...the dots seem to be accelerating 
faster and faster away from the dot you see to be the center...the dots 
furthest out are moving faster than the dots closest in!  Making the fabric 
look to be accelerating even though when you pull on the rubber sheet 
evenly you are NOT accelerating the pull!!!  This analogy according to some 
is fraught with some problems just like also the idea of redshift is 
analogized to be like the Doppler shift but there is really a bit more 
going on...even so, the analogies seem to help...until some-thing better 
comes along.

comments.text:
Lol. You have very high hopes there. We won't ever be able to make it to 
the edge of space within the time of our existence - never mind in our 
lifetimes. We won't even make it past our galaxy in our lifetimes. I worry 
that you haven't even thought about the considerations that you need to 
take when asking such question.

However, I cannot tell you what is beyond space but I can tell you what it 
is not: it is certainly not space for a start - meaning we won't be able 
navigate it. Secondly, there is no such thing as time rendering the law of 
causality impossible - meaning there will be no effects and causes 
happening there. In fact, every known law would not exist since the laws of 
the universe can only be applied to the universe.

Basically, everything that's happening is only happening in here - outside 
of space is either completely dull or completely mind-blowing. Since what 
it would be, is - in a literal sense - out of this world.
comments.author: Descartes Rene

comments.text:
That's when we need to add new words to help establish definitions of 
observations and models we've discovered or made.  Or just modify or 
existing definitions, which maybe easier.  I would change universe to mean 
everything within our space-time causation.  The difference between other 
universes, they don't appear to effect our space-time causation or detach 
from our space-time causation.
I'm coming under the idea based on holographic universe idea-essentially 
points to 3 dimensional space-time arising from a 2 dimensional 
singularity, we're on a singularity which has moment to breed its own 
space-time- we decouple from reference frame of the singularity's time 
outside its locality. To it, we're imaginary time, and to us its imaginary 
time unit.  To me, the idea makes sense of how the Higg's field is 
everywhere throughout the our universe and has a value consistent with more 
than 0, unlike other fields like EM field which has a 0 value until a 
particle excites the field. Singularity we're on is allow our temporal 
projection to have energy to excite the Higg's field-- is the only 
umbilical cord that has any effect on our universe from the singularity. As 
well as making sense to why space appears to be flat, essentially space is 
2 Dimensional-- field energy is causing a projection that expands space 3 
dimensions.  And it fits observation that the expansion of the universe 
happened everywhere-- if we're on a singularity, the emergence of our space 
time would have to be everywhere.  ﻿
